questions.question_text:
A security architect has been assigned to a new digital transformation program. The objectives are to provide better capabilities to customers and reduce costs.
The program has highlighted the following requirements:
1. Long-lived sessions are required, as users do not log in very often.
2. The solution has multiple SPs, which include mobile and web applications.
3. A centralized IdP is utilized for all customer digital channels.
4. The applications provide different functionality types such as forums and customer portals.
5. The user experience needs to be the same across both mobile and web-based applications.
Which of the following would BEST improve security while meeting these requirements?

discussion.content:
Definitely not option A because "implement one-time passwords sent to the mobile device" defeats requirement "5. The user experience needs to be the same across both mobile and web-based applications."

Going with option C. I had gaven186's logic as well.

I choose C. "store refresh tokens securely because they essentially allow a user to remain authenticated forever" this fullfilling #1. 
Cookies works per domain, Token works across multiple domains (SPs).
Token is newer technology that fits better to mobile over cookies. 
The answer A "store cookie securely" doesn't help prolong a session anyway.

comments.content:
Forget two-factor authentication, here comes context-aware authentication
While 2FA is certainly secure, it is a rather blunt instrument and tends to introduce more drag into the logging on process than is ideal.
https://www.computerworld.com/article/3105866/forget-two-factor-authentication-here-comes-context-aware-authentication.html

The original purpose of refresh tokens is to obtain long-term access to an API on behalf of the user. In such long-term scenarios, the user is not always present. Hence, the refresh token allows an application to autonomously obtain a new access token from the security token service, without user intervention.
https://vceguide.com/which-of-the-following-would-best-improve-security-while-meeting-these-requirements/

questions.question_text: An organization is currently performing a market scan for managed security services and EDR capability. Which of the following business documents should be released to the prospective vendors in the first step of the process? (Choose two.)

A security incident responder discovers an attacker has gained access to a network and has overwritten key system files with backdoor software. The server was reimaged and patched offline. Which of the following tools should be implemented to detect similar attacks?

discussion.content: Question want you to detect if the same attack occur again. File Integrity Monitor did just that. D
The diversion here, I'm guessing, is the fact that they talk about the backdoor, when really its asking how to know when key files have been overwritten. The answer is D.
The answer is in fact D - file integrity monitor
At first you would think E, however the question says Detect.

comments.content: A NIPS might detect it also. But file integrity monitor is a better answer.

"An Access-Request message was received from RADIUS client x.x.x.x with a Message-Authenticator attribute that is not valid (bad shared secret)
